questions.question_text: Which two items does an FGFM keepalive message include? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Answer: CD
Pages 280 of FortiManager_7.2_Study_Guide-Online.pdf

Answer: CD 
Keepalive messages, including the configuration checksums, are sent from FortiGate at configured intervals.
The messages also show the intrusion prevention system (IPS) version of the FortiGate device

Selected Answer: CD
C and D are correct

Selected Answer: CD
C: Correct
D: Correct
Page 142& 280(slide) of FortiManager_7.2_Study_Guide-Online.pdf

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Given the configuration shown in the exhibit, which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The FortiManager ADOM workspace mode is set to Normal.
choices.D: The FortiManager ADOM is locked by the administrator.
choices.B: An administrator can also lock the Local-FortiGate-1 policy package.

discussion.content:
B and C
Policy locking is available in workspace normal mode only

Study Guide Page 239

comments.content: Policy locking is available in workspace normal and per-ADOM modes.

discussion.content: B & C is workspace normal mode you can lock individual policy packages and also other users can work and lock other individual policy packages in the same ADOM the same time. Dont bother with any other answers

B and C

B is clear.

Regarding C - Policy locking is available workspace normal or per-ADOM modes. In order to use policy locking you must set workspace-mode to normal.

Selected Answer: BC
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortimanager/7.2.4/administration-guide/397419/lock-an-individual-policy
B and C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: AB
A) Correct. FortiManager is in workflow mode. (the ability to lock individual policies instead of the entire ADOM is present.
B) Correct. Other individual policies can be locked in this example (per policy not per ADOM)
C) Incorrect. Policy locking is available in workspace NORMAL and PER-ADOM (from the study guide under policy lock)
D) Incorrect. This would not show locks on individual policies, it would lock the entire ADOM
A & B are correct in my opinion.

comments.content:
C. The FortiManager ADOM workspace mode is set to Normal.
Not correct as you don't set the workspace mode on a ADOM but on a system global level.

D. The FortiManager ADOM is locked by the administrator. 
Not correct, as this would release the lock on the policy package

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
I think B and C

Selected Answer: AC
PAGE 50

Selected Answer: AC
A and C seems to be correct.

choices.B: FortiManager automatically installs the configuration difference in revisions on the managed FortiGate.
choices.A: It supports the FortiManager script feature.
choices.D: You cannot assign the same ADOM to multiple administrators.
choices.C: It allows making configuration changes for managed devices on FortiManager panes.

choices.A: You must manually move the header and footer policies after the policy assignment.
choices.C: If you assign an additional global policy package to the same ADOM, FortiManager removes previously assigned policies.
choices.D: You can edit or delete all the global objects in the global ADOM.
choices.B: After you assign the global policy package to an ADOM, the policy package is hidden from the ADOM and cannot be viewed.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C & D.

FortiManager 7.2 Study Guide page 259:

- All global objects start with "g" and are edited or deleted in the global ADOM only. 

- Assigning an additional global policy package to the same individual ADOM policy package removes previously assigned policies.

Selected Answer: CD
Option C is correct. If you assign an additional global policy package to the same ADOM, FortiManager may replace or remove previously assigned policies to ensure consistency.
Option D is correct. You should be able to edit or delete global objects within the global ADOM after creating and assigning the global policy package.

Selected Answer: CD
C&D are correct

C = Assigning an additional global policy 
package to the same individual ADOM policy package removes previously assigned policies.

D = After you assign the global ADOM objects, they appear on the Policy & Objects pane for that ADOM. All 
global objects start with "g" and are edited or deleted in the global ADOM only.

Reference [Page 259] - https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortimanager-study-guide-for-fortimanager-72.html

Selected Answer: CD
C & D is correct not A

questions.question_text:
An administrator created a header and footer global policy package and assigned it to an ADOM.
What are two outcomes from this action? (Choose two.)

choices.A: It compares the policy packages with the revision history, and updates policy packages in the ADOM database.
choices.D: It provides recommendations to combine similar policy packages within an ADOM into one single policy package.
choices.B: It provides recommendations for optimizing policies in a policy package.
choices.C: It merges and creates dynamic mappings for duplicate objects used in a policy package.

discussion.content: B as described from OKOT01

Selected Answer: B
B
page 217
https://training.fortinet.com/pluginfile.php/1793163/mod_resource/content/26/FortiManager_7.2_Study_Guide-Online.pdf?forcedownload=1
